question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
If a is different than zero, then the given curve is a polynomial of degree 7. Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = (ax+b)^7\end{aligned}\]

then its derivative (using the chain rule) is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = 7(ax+b)^6 \cdot a = 7a(ax+b)^6\end{aligned}\]

and so the slope of the tangent line to this curve at the point x = b/a is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(b/a) = 7a(a \left( \frac{b}{a} \right) +b)^6 = 7a(2b)^6 = 2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6\end{aligned}\]

And the y coordinate of that point is \(f(b/a)\) which is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(b/a) = (a \left( \frac{b}{a} \right) +b)^7 = (2b)^7 = 2^7b^7\end{aligned}\]

So using the standard equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=m(x-x_0)+y_0\end{aligned}\]

for a line of slope m and going through the point (x0, y0) we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6 (x-\frac{b}{a}) + 2^7b^7\end{aligned}\]

which you can simplify a bit and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6 x - 2^6 \cdot 5 b^7\end{aligned}\]

or if you compute things out

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=448 a b^6 x - 320 b^7\end{aligned}\]

You don’t need to do the last two steps during a test usually.

statement_html:
Let \(y = (ax + b)^7\), where a and b are constant.

(a) Suppose that a ≠ 0. Find the equation of the line tangent to the curve at

\[\begin{aligned} x = \frac{b}{a}.\end{aligned}\]
